Metadata.siteDescription: Borough-by-borough performance grades for Montreal, powered by the city's own open data. Permits, 311 requests, snow removal, and more.

HomePage.heroSubtitle: Is your municipal government performing? Performance grades for each borough, based on the City's open data.
HomePage.ctaTitle: The mayor promised 90 days. We're checking.
HomePage.ctaBody: All data comes from the City of Montreal's open data portal. Updated weekly. No opinions — just the numbers.

metadata.title: Construction Permits — MontréalScore
metadata.description: Tracking construction permit processing times by borough in Montreal.

PermitsPage.title: Construction Permits
PermitsPage.subtitle: Processing times by borough vs the {target}-day target (Mayor Martinez Ferrada's promise). The previous target was {previousTarget} days.
PermitsPage.chartFootnote: Green dashed line = {target}-day target. Colors reflect the borough's grade.
PermitsPage.methodologyText: Processing times are calculated from the date_debut (application date) and date_emission (issuance date) fields in the City of Montreal's open dataset. The median is used instead of the average to reduce the impact of outliers. Data is updated weekly by the City.

AboutPage.title: About MontréalScore
AboutPage.intro: MontréalScore is a free, open-source tool that tracks the performance of Montreal's municipal government, borough by borough, using the City's open data.
AboutPage.whyBody: Mayor Soraya Martinez Ferrada promised a maximum 90-day turnaround for construction permits. The previous administration had set a 120-day target. Currently, the median processing time exceeds 200 days in some boroughs. No public dashboard exists to verify whether these targets are being met.
AboutPage.whyBody2: MontréalScore fills that gap. No opinions. No bias. Just the numbers.
AboutPage.dataSourcesIntro: All data comes from <link>Montreal's open data portal</link>. Datasets used include:
AboutPage.methodologyIntro: Each borough receives a grade from A to F based on a composite score of 0 to 100. For permits, the score considers:
AboutPage.methodologyMedian: Median processing time vs the 90-day target (40%)
AboutPage.methodologyPct: Percentage of permits processed on time (40%)
AboutPage.methodologyNote: Grades are both relative (borough vs borough) and absolute (borough vs its own targets).
AboutPage.openSourceBody: Source code is available on <link>GitHub</link>. Contributions welcome.
AboutPage.contactBody: MontréalScore is a project by <link>Brulé AI</link>.

ContractsPage.title: Municipal Contracts
ContractsPage.subtitle: All contracts over $2,000 approved by the City of Montreal. Data from the open data portal.
ContractsPage.concentrationSubtitle: What share of municipal spending goes to the largest suppliers?
ContractsPage.concentrationDetail: of spending goes to the top {count} suppliers
ContractsPage.distributionSubtitle: Number of contracts by value range. Highlighted bars border Quebec procurement thresholds.
ContractsPage.distributionFootnote: Highlighted bars = ranges adjacent to $25K (no formal process) and $139K (mandatory public tender, 2026-2027 threshold) thresholds.
ContractsPage.thresholdSubtitle: In Quebec, contracts under $25K require no formal process. Above the public tender threshold, a public call for tenders is mandatory. The threshold has changed over time ($100K in 2017, $101.1K in 2019, $105.7K in 2022, $121.2K in late 2022, $133.8K in 2024, $139K in 2026). The analysis below applies the threshold in effect at each contract's approval date.
ContractsPage.thresholdMethodology: Comparison uses a symmetric value band above the threshold as baseline. The threshold applied matches the one in effect at each contract's approval date. A ratio significantly above 1 may indicate contract splitting. Sources: <lcv>art. 573.3.1.2, Loi sur les cités et villes</lcv> ($25K threshold); <mamh>MAMH — Conformité des contrats municipaux</mamh> (public tender thresholds, adjusted biennially via Muni-Express).
ContractsPage.methodologyText: Data comes from the "Contrats de la Ville de Montréal" dataset on the open data portal. All contracts of $2,000 and above are published. Amounts are in Canadian dollars.
